content:
Damn, I got 80% on this in shortest mode after getting 100% on test cases.
It's because none of your test cases involve an input like "08" or "09" which when evaluated in Ruby cause "Invalid octal digit" errors.
Validator 1 throws this error. It would be nice to have a test case involving a number like this so that clashers can debug this before submitting overly-shortened code.

Perfect for a clash.
I think reverse mode would be too hard even with hh:mm format.
I think reverse mode would be possible if the input were phrased as a time, e.g. 6:20, and if the first example were something like 9:00.
Not to hard not to easy. Good.

As the output can be a float (half an integer at least), you have to specify the expected output format. You should as well give more details about the input format.
I also agree with eaarslew below: This problem is not reasonable for reverse mode.

Good little puzzle with a small catch, since not everyone will get that the hour hand in rarely exactly on the hour position. Maybe a hint on this in the text should be considered, or a picture of an analog clock at 12:30 in the example text.

But I don't think that the puzzle works for reverse mode. It would be very hard to figure out that we're dealing with clock hands and angles on an analog clock based on the input/output alone - and the math is not easily discovered without that knowledge.
From my point of view reverse is not to hard because of the formatting. (06, 20)
Why this is easier? Time --> number? I added a clear testcase, maybe it's better now. But i agree yout format is clearer

>not everyone will get that the hour hand in rarely exactly on the hour position
Nah, that's pretty easy to get and getting that is required to pass all sample tests.
What is kinda real challenge is to read "smaller angle". Only one last sample test doesn't pass if you just gonna abs(hh-mm). May be confusing.
